importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update, indicating recent developments in the NYC mayoral race involving Curtis Sliwa and Republican efforts to pressure him out.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which key developments in the mayoral race unfolded, including Catsimatidis' public call for Sliwa to drop out, Trump's dismissive comments, and Sliwa's rebuttal in debate and interview.

keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, is facing pressure from his boss John Catsimatidis to withdraw from the race.
John Catsimatidis, a lifelong New Yorker and owner of WABC radio, publicly urged Sliwa to exit, citing concerns about Sliwa's commitment to New York.
Republican figures, including Andrew Cuomo (running as an independent), are pushing Sliwa out of the race to unite opposition against Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, a democratic socialist.
Sliwa has rejected the pressure, asserting that he represents blue-collar working-class voters and criticizing Cuomo's reliance on billionaire donations.
President Donald Trump dismissed Sliwa as 'not exactly primetime' and mocked his love of cats and animal rescues, indicating broader Republican skepticism.
Sliwa has been on leave from WABC radio since launching his mayoral campaign, highlighting the personal and professional stakes involved.
Andrew Cuomo labeled Sliwa as a 'shock jock' and claimed he is not a viable alternative to Mamdani, suggesting he is not a serious contender.
Mamdani has dismissed claims of coordination between him and Sliwa, emphasizing that voters should decide who runs, not billionaire donors.
Sliwa is polling third in the race behind Mamdani and Cuomo, showing he remains a significant, though not leading, contender.
Sliwa's campaign is framed as a counter to elite political influence, positioning him as a voice for working-class New Yorkers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican mayoral candidate in New York City, is under pressure from his boss John Catsimatidis and other Republicans to drop out of the race, as they seek to consolidate opposition against Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, a democratic socialist. John Catsimatidis, owner of WABC radio and Sliwa’s former boss, publicly urged Sliwa to withdraw, arguing that he should love New York more than anything else. Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, has also pushed Sliwa out, dismissing him as a 'shock jock' and claiming he is not a viable alternative. In response, Sliwa has defended his candidacy, asserting he represents blue-collar voters and criticizing the influence of billionaire donors. President Donald Trump dismissed Sliwa as 'not exactly primetime' and mocked his cat-related interests, reflecting broader skepticism. Sliwa, who founded the Guardian Angels and has run for mayor before, is polling third in the race, and while facing internal and external pressure, he maintains that voters should have the final say.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
